frame.name: Reference_text
frame.definition:
<def-root>In a text, a <fen>Source_of_information</fen> is given that provides a reader of the text with further <fen>Information</fen> relevant to the text. In this frame the author and reader are completely deprofiled, with the <fen>Source_of_information</fen> made salient.
<ex>In Densmore's days it was sometimes made of an old-fashioned man's celluloid collar (<t>cf.</t> <fex name="soi">Densmore 1943: 116</fex>).</ex>
<ex>The 'foaming regions' play the role of 'internal shocks' (<t>cf.</t> <fex name="soi">Piran's recent publication</fex> <fex name="inf">for a review</fex>) of GRB theory.</ex>
<ex>Use my() for local variables whenever you can get away with it (but <t>see</t> <fex name="soi">perlform</fex> <fex name="inf">for where you can't</fex>).</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Source_of_information
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Source_of_information</fen> is referred to as a source of information related to the current text.
<ex>The accreting matter forms a disc whose instabilities trigger outbursts (<t>see</t> <fex name="soi">Lasota 2001</fex> for a review of the instability model).</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Information
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Source_of_information</fen> contains <fen>Information</fen> that the reader is directed to.
<ex>The accreting matter forms a disc whose instabilities trigger outbursts (<t>see</t> Lasota 2001 <fex name="inf">for a review of the instability model</fex>). </ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: qv.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: used to direct a reader to another part of a text for further information.

lexUnit.name: refer.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: to consult a source of information.
